article.title: Accretion signatures in the X-shooter spectrum of the substellar companion to SR12

multiple_choice_question.text: What discrepancy is evident between the theoretical and observed spectra in the K band?
choices: The observed spectrum shows significantly less flux than the theoretical model.
The observed spectrum shows a sharp emission line not present in the model.
The observed spectrum shows significantly more flux than the theoretical model.
The observed and theoretical spectra match perfectly in the K band.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements about the spectral fitting using observational templates is TRUE?
choices: The L4 object Gl417B from the SINFONI library provides a good fit to the SR12C spectrum.
The best fit from the SpeX library is obtained with an object classified as M9 at both optical and NIR wavelengths.
The SINFONI library does not contain a spectrum of an object with a similar spectral type as SR12C.
Both the SINFONI and Spex Prism libraries indicate a spectral type of LO for SR12C.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the irregular shape and the top part of the fitted HÎ± line indicate?
choices: Presence of a close binary companion.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend is suggested by the data points in this figure regarding the accretion status of SSCs?
choices: SSCs of all ages are equally likely to be accreting.
Older SSCs are more likely to be accreting compared to younger ones.
Younger SSCs are more likely to be accreting compared to older ones.
There is no apparent correlation between the age of an SSC and its accretion status.
